title: Selling a typeface as an Illustrator file
content: If a typeface is very graphic/display or contains gradients or whatnot which only ai.- format allows, leaving kerning to the customer.... Some graphic vector elements are sold that way. Would it be a good idea for a typeface?
author: Mikhail Kovalev

comments.content:
If you mean for it to be used as a graphic then it's perfectly fine to sell it as an illustration. One example of which is the high rez scanned woodtype from [http://www.withoutwalls.com/index.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20131014225833/http:/www.withoutwalls.com/index.htm "http://www.withoutwalls.com/index.htm")

Letterror used to sell it's [Federal typefaces](http://web.archive.org/web/20131014225833/http:/www.letterror.com/catalog/fed/index.html) as an illustrator file that you could typeset online. And soon House Industries will offer the same old-school technique made new with an online version of the [Photo-Lettering](http://web.archive.org/web/20131014225833/http:/www.photo-lettering.com/) catalog.

Not sure if that could be called a [typeface](http://web.archive.org/web/20131014225833/http:/typophile.com/wiki/typeface). It would definitely NOT be a [font](http://web.archive.org/web/20131014225833/http:/typophile.com/wiki/font).

(Difference between "typeface" and "font": [http://blogs.adobe.com/typblography/2005/12/quality\_in\_type.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20131014225833/http:/blogs.adobe.com/typblography/2005/12/quality_in_type.html "http://blogs.adobe.com/typblography/2005/12/quality\_in\_type.html"))
I can't imagine there would be a (big) market for typefaces in AI.-format, but if it's anything like Ken's links, I'd for one be a potential customer ;-)
Emigre's Missionary shipped as EPS files—as well as a font—at the time when I licensed it. For some work this could be preferable.
Ken, would you please point me to a source article about House putting the photo-lettering stuff online? I'd love to read more about it.

You could search around for more but there was an article in the MAR/APR 2005 issue of Print Magazine.

[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi\_hb4324/is\_200503/ai\_n15074400](http://web.archive.org/web/20131014225833/http:/findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_hb4324/is_200503/ai_n15074400 "http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi\_hb4324/is\_200503/ai\_n15074400")
